title: Australian shares in weekly advance as IOOF, CYBG rally
text:
IOOF shares jumped 16.6 per cent to $7.30 during the week. The price that IOOF will pay to acquire ANZ Bank's pensions and investments arm was reduced by $125 million.

The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority will not appeal a Federal Court decision that cleared the wealth business and five of its executives and directors of misconduct.

CYBG shares rallied 14.4 per cent to $2.46 after the UK and the European Union agreed to a divorce deal which remains subject to a parliamentary vote on Saturday.

Earnings guidance helped Fisher & Paykel, up 10 per cent to $17.55 over the week, and Steadfast, up 8.3 per cent to $3.66 during the week, to advance.

But furniture retailer Nick Scali, down 10.8 per cent to $6.19 over the week, and Southern Cross Media, down 22.7 per cent to 89¢ during the week suffered after weak trading updates.

Nick Scali warned that net profit could fall as much as 32 per cent in the December half following a sharp slump in sales over the past few months.

Southern Cross Media shares hit their lowest level since 2014 after the company blamed the weak advertising market for an 8.5 per cent hit to revenue.

Advertisement

Seven West Media gained 5.5 per cent to 39¢ during the week. It said on Friday it will merge with Prime Media Group and divest its Western Australian radio assets (Redwave) to Southern Cross Media for $28 million.

Afterpay Touch slid 15.6 per cent over the week to $29.65. UBS predicted the buy now, pay later juggernaut would see its share price halve within a year thanks to looming regulatory risks. The investment bank initiated coverage on the company with a "sell" rating.

On Friday, the Reserve Bank said it will investigate whether "policy action" is required to target buy now, pay later operators which prevent merchants from passing the costs to customers.

WiseTech Global shares slid 12.4 per cent to $30 over the week before trading was halted on Thursday after a report by hedge fund research firm J Capital accused the company of using accounting trickery to inflate growth and overstate profits. The $10 billion target had not responded to JCap's claims as of the close of trading on Friday.

Gold miners were under pressure over the week, with Northern Star Resources falling 14.4 per cent to $10.15 after telling the market that production was down almost 40,000 ounces compared with the previous three months and, on top of that, sales had slowed as well.

St Barbara shares slid 9 per cent to $2.53 after the firm on Friday reduced production guidance for its West Australian Gwalia facility, while subsequently raising expenditure targets and all-in sustaining cost predictions.

Elsewhere in the sector, Pilbara Resources posted a weekly drop of 8 per cent to 28¢ a share while Independence Group dropped 8 per cent to $5.75.

China released gross domestic product data on Friday, with growth printing at 6 per cent year-on-year, the slowest pace in 30 years, down from 6.2 per cent in the second quarter and a weaker result than the 6.1 per cent growth that economists had been expecting.
description: Profit expectations and dealmaking helped lift the Australian market to a weekly gain of 0.7 per cent despite wobbles in the tech sector.
